description: From Scots forgather, foregather (“to gather up, assemble”), equivalent to for- +‎ gather. Cognate with Dutch vergaderen (“to assemble”), German vergattern (“to assemble; to assign duty”).

verbs.description: forgather (third-person singular simple present forgathers, present participle forgathering, simple past and past participle forgathered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To assemble or gather together in one place, to gather up; to congregate.
examples: “I can tell you where to find them,’ she said, ‘with a fair degree of certainty; they foregather almost every evening about this time at a rather disreputable old pub.’
